title: How to Arrange a Kitchen Without Cabinets

steps.headline: Measure how much space essential kitchen objects need.
steps.description: Select only the items you know you need to keep in the kitchen, such as your favorite coffee machine or foods you regularly keep in stock. Use a tape measure to record a rough estimate of the item’s dimensions. This can be laborious, but it will give you an idea of how to organize your kitchen. For example, measure the base of the toaster to find out how much counter space it needs. It’s usually small and can be stored or surrounded by other objects. Don’t forget that it needs to be near an outlet. Measuring the countertop space is a good idea, too. This will help you see how much countertop space you have to work with when arranging the kitchen.

steps.headline: Clear storage space on the ground or walls and sketch a plan.
steps.description: Look for any place where you can create extra space. Move anything not essential, such as wall decorations or cans or boxes on the ground, out of the kitchen temporarily. With paper and pencil, draw a basic outline of your kitchen in order to visualize your perfectly arranged kitchen. One of the biggest advantages is vertical space. Without upper cabinets, there is plenty of room to hang shelves and other storage options.

steps.headline: Store the most useful items where they are easy to reach.
steps.description: Commonly used items, such as cooking utensils, can be hung on hooks near the stove or placed on wall racks. Items you use infrequently can be placed on the back ends of shelves or moved to a different room. Use this tactic to organize food, too. For example, the peanut butter jar you plan on opening every day can stay near the front of a top shelf or basket. Place canned food you use sparingly in the back.

steps.headline: Throw out food and appliances you don’t use.
steps.description: Maximize your space by clearing out any expired food. If an appliance doesn’t fit in your plan, it may be time to give it away or donate it to a thrift store. You won’t have a cabinet where you can store cans or boxes and forget them. You will always have to be careful about what you accumulate in your kitchen and actively remove what you don’t need.

steps.headline: Move excess supplies to an adjoining room to clear space.
steps.description: Also install shelves, carts, and cabinets in other rooms to hold items you can’t keep in a kitchen. Turn a closet into a pantry to further make up for the lack of kitchen storage space. These storage options often are useful as decorations in a dining room. For instance, plate racks are great ways to store and display plates in the dining room as well as the kitchen.

steps.headline: Organize counter and drawer space with plastic bins.
steps.description: Gather up your remaining supplies and group similar items into bins. Purchase bins at general stores such as Walmart. These bins fit in deep drawers or on countertops, so they’re perfect for saving space by staying organized. For example, you can have a bin for bread, a bin for fruit, and a bin for vegetables.

methods.name: Creating Storage Space on the Wall

steps.headline: Install open shelving on empty walls.
steps.description: Purchase shelving or create your own by mounting metal pipes to the wall and hanging wood boards on them. Place the shelves where the upper cabinets would be and use them to store anything, including plates and glasses. Remember to measure your kitchen’s wall space first to buy or install shelves that fit. Whatever you store here will be visible, so consider it to be a part of the kitchen’s decorations.

steps.headline: Fill tight corners with plate racks.
steps.description: Plate racks are another way to turn kitchen supplies into wall decorations and may be purchased at home decoration stores. Hang a rack by screwing it to the wall. Then slide the plates into the grooves on the racks. Plate racks fit well in corners or on narrow walls where you can’t fit other storage options.

steps.headline: Hang a pegboard for organized general storage.
steps.description: Pegboards are boards with pre-drilled, evenly-spaced holes. Mount the pegboard by screwing it to the wall, then use pegboard hangers to hang anything you want. A pegboard is useful for organizing pots, pans, cooking utensils, and even hanging knife displays. Installing the pegboard will create holes in the wall, which can be filled with spackling once you remove the board. An old door with slats can also serve as a pegboard. Stand it up and screw it to the wall.

steps.headline: Use adhesive hooks near the stove to hang cooking utensils.
steps.description: You can purchase individual hooks or bars with multiple hooks from most general stores and home stores. Peel the backing off the hooks, then press them against the wall to stick them in place. While you’re cooking, you’ll easily be able to reach for utensils such as a spatula or spoon. You may also find hooks or bars that screw into the wall. These require more work to install, but won’t fall off under heavy weights.

steps.headline: Set up curtain rod on the wall to hold pans.
steps.description: Screw the curtain rod’s brackets into the wall, then hang the rod on them. Get some S-shaped hooks if they weren’t included with the rod. The hooks are useful for hanging pots, pans and mugs. The rods can be placed on any wall, including spots where you don’t have a lot of other storage options.

steps.headline: Hang curtain rods above windows and doors to save space.
steps.description: First, measure the length of the largest pot or pan. Use this measurement to hang the rod so the pots and pans don’t obstruct the window or door. Hang the pots and pans on S-shaped hooks. Anything that hangs too low will prevent light from entering the window or bump your head when you walk through the door, so be careful.

steps.headline: Hang a ceiling-mounted pot rack to save on wall space.
steps.description: Drill holes in the ceiling joists, then attach the rack to them with hooks and chains. Adjust the chains to raise or lower the rack to the proper height. Then, use S-shaped hooks to hang the pots and pans for easy access. Ceiling pot racks work well over kitchen islands and other spaces you won’t walk through.

steps.headline: Bring in rolling carts for mobile storage.
steps.description: Rolling carts are affordable options at general stores and home decoration stores. Many of them have multiple shelves in addition to being mobile. Place these in tight corners or against a wall where nothing else fits. Rolling carts can be stored in a different room and wheeled into the kitchen when needed.

steps.headline: Set up ground bins to hold excess supplies.
steps.description: Bins come in various sizes and materials, so you can use them to fill in any space in your kitchen. They’re especially good for creating space under sinks, storage carts, or anywhere else you can fit them. Store canned food or spare objects you can’t fit elsewhere. For example, buy plastic storage bins at a general store. Alternatively, use cardboard boxes or wooden baskets.

steps.headline: Bring in a mobile island to fill space in the center of the kitchen.
steps.description: Mobile islands are similar to rolling carts and can be purchased at general stores and home decoration stores. The island’s top surface is a countertop. Most islands also have drawers or storage shelves below that for extra storage space. Like rolling carts, mobile islands have wheels, so they can be moved into another room for storage. However, they’re typically bigger than carts and meant to be left in the center of your kitchen.

steps.headline: Place stacking shelves to add more counter space.
steps.description: Extend the legs on the shelves and stack them on top of each other on the counter. They’re great for holding anything for quick access, such as large bowls and pans. The shelves will provide vertical space in your kitchen while still leaving space for countertop items like microwaves and cutting boards.
